1:18:54  sexual dimorphism and its implications on: - aggression: species with bigger male-female size differences have more aggressive males . - reproductive success: species with bigger male-female size differences have lower variability in reproductive success. Here, the males must fight one another for reproductive access so the few strongest males have the most access to females . - sexual selection: species with bigger male-female size differences have females with a greater preference for larger male size. If your man will provide nothing but genes, get a man with good genes at least . - male parental behaviour: species with smaller male-female size differences have females who have a preference for males displaying paternal behaviour (competent males, not just big and aggressive males; hence some birds court by bringing females food to show capacity to provide.  . - life expectancy: species with larger male-female size differences have lower life spans for the males.  . - proclivity for twins (i.e. multiple offspring simultaneously). Smaller dimorphism = higher likelihood of twins as two parents put effort into raising the offspring.  . - child abandonment to pursue a higher ranking male: smaller dimorphism groups do this more often as the fathers would remain looking after the offspring    Tournament species (larger sexual dimorphism: males with big bright plumage e.g. peacock feathers, chicken pecking orders, baboons)  And  Pair-bonding, monogamous species (less sexual dimorphism, males and females difficult to distinguish by appearance)  Humans are somewhat in the middle

typedef struct Node {     char data;     struct Node* next; } Node;  Node* create_node(char data) {     Node* new_node = (Node*)malloc(sizeof(Node));     new_node->data = data;     new_node->next = NULL;     return new_node; }  void insert_node(Node** head, char data) {     Node* new_node = create_node(data);     if (*head == NULL) {         *head = new_node;     } else {         Node* temp = *head;         while (temp->next != NULL) {             temp = temp->next;         }         temp->next = new_node;     } }  char* linked_list_to_string(Node* head) {     int length = 0;     Node* temp = head;     while (temp != NULL) {         length++;         temp = temp->next;     }          char* str = (char*)malloc((length + 1) * sizeof(char));     temp = head;     int i = 0;     while (temp != NULL) {         str[i++] = temp->data;         temp = temp->next;     }     str[i] = '\0';     return str; }  void free_list(Node* head) {     Node* temp;     while (head != NULL) {         temp = head;         head = head->next;         free(temp);     } }  char* encrypt(const char* message, int key) {     int len = strlen(message);     char* encrypted = (char*)malloc((len + 1) * sizeof(char));     for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {         if (message[i] >= 'A' && message[i] <= 'Z') {             encrypted[i] = ENCRYPT(message[i], key);         } else {             encrypted[i] = message[i];         }     }     encrypted[len] = '\0';     return encrypted; }  char* decrypt(const char* message, int key) {     int len = strlen(message);     char* decrypted = (char*)malloc((len + 1) * sizeof(char));     for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {         if (message[i] >= 'A' && message[i] <= 'Z') {             decrypted[i] = DECRYPT(message[i], key);         } else {             decrypted[i] = message[i];         }     }     decrypted[len] = '\0';     return decrypted; }

تتوفر الحيوانات والأنواع على سمات يمكن توريثها . - تتميز هذه الصفات والسمات بالإختلاف . - بعض هذه السمات متكيفة ( أي أنها تتكيف مع الطبيعة) أكثر من الأخرى .  وبإضافة عنصر آخر وهو الطفرات التي بدورها مسؤولة عن ظهور سمات جديدة ، باضافة هذا العنصر فإنك بامكانك الحصول على تغيرات كبيرة في المجموعة .  ويمضي سابولسكي قدما في محاضرته محاولا أن يطبق نفس المبادئ لكن لا على الصفات وإنما على السلوك الإنساني :  - تتوفر الحيوانات على سلوكات يمكن توريثها. - سلوكات مختلفة . - بعضها متكيف أكثر من الآخر وبالتالي الأكثر تكيفا سيكون أكثر شيوعا .  - وعنصر الطفرة الذي يؤدي إلى ظهور سلوكات جديدة .   ويوضح سابولسكي فكرة مفادها أن من بين أكثر الأفكار التي تم الترويج لها وإشاعتها ( فكرة التصرف من أجل مصلحة النوع ، وإنتقاء المجموعة ) هي فكرة خاطئة وتعتبر من أساطير التطور وهي فكرة يجب التخلص منها على الرغم من أننا أحيانا إذا أمعنا النظر في مملكة الحيوان سنجد أن بعض السلوكات قد تبدو كأنها من أجل مصلحة النوع لكنها حقا ليست كذلك .   والحيوانات تتصرف لا من أجل مصلحة النوع لكن بل من أجل مصلحة النسل، أي أنها تتصرف من أجل أن ترفع من نقلها ونسخها وتوريثها للجينات ،ويحدث ذلك عبر ثلاثة آليات تمكننا من فهم السلوك الإجتماعي بسياق نظرية التطور : - الإنتخاب الفردي زيادة تمرير جيناتك عبر مضاعفة تناسلك ونسخك لجيناتك . - الإنتخاب بالقرابة ، أحيانا الطريقة المثلى لتمرير جيناتك هي التخلي عن تناسلك ومساعدة قريبك . - الإيثار التبادلي ، أي الإيثار تجاه غير الأقارب ، والتعاون ، الشيء الذي يطرح إشكالا هو مسألة الغش ، الذي ينهي التعاون المنبني على المنفعة المتبادلة ، من هنا أهمية التعرف على الغش وتمييزه ، ومن هنا نستنتج إن هذه الحيوانات يجب إن تتوفر على قدر من الذكاء لتميز الغش ، ومعرفة الوقت التي تغش فيه هي أيضا والوقت الذي تتوقف فيه عن التعاون ، حيونات يجب أن تكون متطورة ،لكن الأمر ليس كذلك إذ تلاحظ مثل هذه السلوكيات عند البكتيريا والفطريات الخ .   الشيء الذي يجعلنا ننحى منحا آخر إلى مجال آخر لدراسة هذا النوع من السلوك وهو نظرية اللعبة ، التي تدرس استراتيجيات التعاون والغش والمصلحة الذاتية والمصلحة المتبادلة ،   فنرى أن الحيوانات طورت استراتيجياتها المثلى لمتى تتعاون ومتى تغش .  ويؤكد من خلال أمثلة قدمها أنه مهما تكن سمات وصفات حيوان معين ، يكون بمقدورنا إذا ما طبقنا المبادئ الثلاثة : الإنتقاء الفردي ، انتقاء القرابة والإيثار التبادلي ، يكون بمقدورنا التنبؤ بالسلوك الإجتماعي لهذا الحيوان .

00:00:00 - Introduction to the video about Behavioral Evolution. 01:14:55 - Discussion about a historical figure, the first person to get a PhD in Computer Sciences, and his interest in game theory evolution. 01:15:22 - Introduction to the possibility of a strategy changing through mutation and its impact on studying evolution. 01:15:52 - Exploration of reciprocal altruism and its role in natural selection, mentioning cooperative hunting in various species. 01:16:21 - Discussion on how sexual selection plays out in reciprocal altruism, using the example of preparing for prom. 01:16:49 - Overview of the three building blocks in evolutionary thought: individual selection, inclusive fitness kin selection, and reciprocal altruism. 01:17:19 - Explanation of kin selection and its relation to cooperation among related organisms. 01:17:48 - Teaser about exploring in detail the challenges in determining relatedness among different species. 01:18:17 - Further discussion on reciprocal altruism, tit for tat, and its optimization in formal games. 01:18:47 - Reflection on applying evolutionary principles to understand various domains of animal behavior and introducing the concept of tournament species vs. pair bonding species.

There is another potential flaw in the tit for tat strategy that has to do with the stakes involved.   Unless I’m mistaken, the games as described have constant outcomes for every trial.  If the stakes are different for different trials and, in particular, if the stakes increase exponentially, it may be that a tit for tat strategy will walk gullible players into ruin.   In terms of value to the general population, if the gains and losses are a percentage of accumulated wealth from playing this game, then increased oscillations between cheating, getting cheated, both having the same response would cause a net negative effect on everyone forced to play the same tit for tat strategy; this is an application of the volatility drag.  This net negative on everyone would be proportional to the variation of outcomes in this compounding scheme.    In short, I do not think the tit for tat strategy is optimal unless every trial has a constant stake (could be different for different actions-opposition action combinations but constant set of potential outcomes for each trial).

🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:00 🎓 Introduction and Course Enrollment - Stanford professor Robert Sapolsky introduces the course and discusses student enrollment, motivations, and humorous responses from the questionnaire. 03:22 🧠 The Biology of Religiosity and Interests - Sapolsky talks about student interests and preferences, including the topic of the biology of religiosity. 04:18 🧬 Applying Darwinian Principles - Sapolsky discusses applying Darwinian principles to understanding behavior and the concept of natural selection. 07:36 🌍 Sociobiology and Evolutionary Psychology - The emergence of sociobiology and evolutionary psychology as disciplines to understand behavior in the context of evolution. 12:50 🦁 Individual Selection - The concept of individual selection, where behavior aims to maximize the number of copies of an individual's genes in the next generation. 22:50 🏃‍♂️ Understanding Behavioral Evolution - The lecture introduces the concept of behavioral evolution and natural selection. - Key ideas: individual selection, passing on genes, maximizing reproductive success. 26:05 🧬 Kin Selection and Inclusive Fitness - The section discusses kin selection and the role of relatedness in behavior. - Key points: kin selection, inclusive fitness, cooperation with relatives. 30:18 🤝 Reciprocal Altruism - The lecture delves into reciprocal altruism and cooperation among non-relatives. - Key ideas: reciprocal altruism, cooperation, vigilance against cheaters. 35:04 🎮 Game Theory and the Prisoner's Dilemma - The section introduces game theory and the classic example of the Prisoner's Dilemma. - Key takeaways: optimal strategies, rationality, the role of pleasure in decision-making. 45:39 💻 Robert Axelrod's Contribution - Discusses Robert Axelrod's pivotal role in the field of game theory through his tournament involving various strategies. - Key point: Axelrod's computerized tournament and its impact on the study of cooperation. 46:08 🐟 Reciprocal altruism in vampire bats and signal error - Vampire bats exhibit reciprocal altruism, cooperating to feed each other's babies. - Signal error can disrupt this cooperation, leading to tit-for-tat retaliation. 50:47 🐟 Forgiving tit for tat and transitioning to trust - Forgiving tit for tat strategy emerges to counter signal errors. - Transitioning to trusting others when no cheating occurs. 54:25 🐟 Exploiting forgiving tit for tat with Pavlov - The Pavlov strategy can exploit forgiving tit for tat. - The introduction of signal error impacts strategies. 01:02:29 🐟 Reciprocal altruism in vampire bats and signal error - Vampire bats exhibit reciprocal altruism, cooperating to feed each other's babies. - Signal error can disrupt this cooperation, leading to tit-for-tat retaliation. 01:06:21 🐟 Tit-for-tat in stickleback fish - Stickleback fish exhibit tit-for-tat behavior against their own reflection when they perceive cheating. - Exploring reciprocal strategies within a single fish. 01:08:13 🦁 Lions' Reciprocal Altruism - Craig Packer's research on lions in East Africa shows reciprocal altruism even among non-relatives. - Observations of a scaredy cat lion challenging the expected tit-for-tat behavior introduced a puzzle. - Real-world complexities such as individuals playing multiple games simultaneously and role diversification became evident. 01:12:02 🐀 Naked Mole Rats' Role Diversification - Naked mole rats live in cooperative colonies with non-relatives and display reciprocity. - Some individuals in these colonies don't participate in labor but play an essential role in defense. - Role diversification highlights the complexity of real-world social interactions. 01:14:25 💻 James Holland's Mutation in Game Theory - James Holland introduced the idea of mutations in game theory, studying how they affect strategies and behaviors. - Mutations can lead to the evolution of different strategies, influencing behavior. - This concept demonstrates the realism of game theory in understanding behavior in various species. 01:19:16 👫 Male-Female Body Size Differences - Species with significant sexual dimorphism in body size tend to have more male aggression. - High variability in male reproductive success is found in species with sexual dimorphism. - In species with low sexual dimorphism, females choose males who exhibit paternal behavior and competence. 01:25:57 ⌛️ Gender-Based Life Span Differences - Species with substantial sexual dimorphism in body size often show differences in life expectancy between genders. - Species with low sexual dimorphism have similar life spans for both males and females. - These differences arise from energy allocation, metabolism, and reproductive strategies. 01:26:53 👶 Giving Birth to Twins in Primates - Primates with low sexual dimorphism typically give birth to twins, and both offspring tend to survive. - Species with high sexual dimorphism cannot support twin offspring due to limited resources. - The decision to abandon or care for offspring depends on the level of male parental investment. 01:27:48 👪 Tournament vs. Pair Bonding Species - Tournament species display strong sexual dimorphism and competition for mates. - Pair bonding species have less sexual dimorphism, and males actively participate in parenting. - The differences in mating strategies and behaviors result from investment in reproduction. 01:30:12 🦍 Evolution of Primate Behavior - Explanation of sexual dimorphism in primates, such as baboons. - Tournament species with male-male aggression and large males. - Influence of energy allocation and parental behavior on reproduction. 01:31:09 🐒 Pair Bonding in South American Monkeys - Description of pair bonding species, exemplified by South American monkeys. - Lack of sexual dimorphism and differences in social behavior compared to tournament species. - High reproductive rates, shared parental care, and low aggression in pair bonding species. 01:32:37 🦉 Consistency Across Species - Discussion of consistent patterns between different species, including birds, fish, and primates. - The dichotomy between tournament species and pair bonding species. - Factors contributing to low variability in pair bonding species. 01:33:34 🌍 Where Do Humans Fit? - Exploration of human characteristics, placing humans in between tournament and pair bonding species. - Examination of sexual dimorphism, variability, and lifespan. - The complexity of human relationships, including monogamy and polygamy in different cultures. 01:35:00 💑 Human Polygamy - Faust" ist ein Drama von Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, das die Geschichte eines Gelehrten namens Faust erzählt. Faust ist unzufrieden mit seinem Leben und sehnt sich nach Wissen und einem tieferen Sinn. Er schließt einen Pakt mit dem Teufel namens Mephistopheles, der ihm Macht, Vergnügen und Jugend verspricht. Faust erlebt verschiedene Abenteuer und Romanzen, darunter seine Beziehung zu einer jungen Frau namens Gretchen. Am Ende bereut Faust seine Entscheidungen und sucht nach Erlösung. Das Drama erkundet Themen wie die Suche nach Wahrheit, das Streben nach Glück und die moralische Verantwortung des Einzelnen. Es ist ein Meisterwerk der deutschen Literatur und gilt als eines der bedeutendsten Werke der Weltliteratur.

Summary :   1. Heritability and variability of traits in populations  The heritability and variability of traits in populations play a significant role in determining the success of species. Mutations introduce new traits, and adaptiveness helps ensure that more copies of genes pass on to the next generation. The genetic components in behaviors, including group selection, individual selection, and sexual selection, optimize gene reproduction and relatedness.  2. Kin selection and inclusive fitness in animal behavior  Animals like primates have the ability to track kinship and optimize behavior based on relatedness. Inclusive fitness and kin selection theories explain why organisms help relatives to increase reproductive success in order to maximize future success. A study with vervet monkeys in Tanzania showed evidence for inclusive fitness and kin selection through different vocalizations and responses to alarm calls.  3. Reciprocal altruism in animals and bacteria  Reciprocal altruism, a system of cooperation among non-relatives, exists in long-lived social vertebrates and bacteria/fungi. Social behavior entails reciprocal relationships, with detecting cheating being crucial. Animals exhibit true cooperation, unlike the mere truce in competition seen between bacteria and humans. Cooperative behavior, like cooperative hunting and food sharing, increases the likelihood of success and reciprocity.  4. Science of cooperation and cheating through game theory  Game theory explores the balance between cooperation and cheating in social species like humans and chimps. The Prisoner's Dilemma model is often used to study cooperation and defection in various situations. The most successful strategy for cooperation is tit for tat, which involves starting with cooperation and reciprocating the other person's behavior in subsequent rounds. However, forgiving tit for tat and other strategies can be effective in certain scenarios. Perceived madness in game theory can also lead to optimal benefits and cooperation.  5. Reciprocal strategies in animal societies  Animals in the wild exhibit reciprocal strategies like tit for tat, where cooperation is rewarded and cheating is punished. This behavior is observed in fish, bats, and naked mole rats. Some individuals in these societies do not contribute to work and are not punished but exhibit non-cooperative behavior. Vampire bats and stickleback fish use a tit for tat strategy to respond to signals and errors. Certain fish species, such as black hamlet fish, can strategically change gender.  6. Optimization and altruism in evolution  Game theory and optimization applications help understand behavior and design optimal strategies, including the evolution of optimal strategies, reciprocal altruism, cooperative hunting, and sexual selection in various species. The discussion also covers three ways to optimize gene copies in the next generation and how humans uniquely determine kinship, leading to reciprocal altruism and vigilance against cheating.  7. Mating and parental behavior in different species  Male aggression and reproductive success are influenced by female choice and differential access. Female mate choice aims to produce genetically well-endowed offspring. In some species, male parental behavior is crucial to offspring survival and is influenced by female choice for desirable traits. Sexual dimorphism and social structure vary among species, with humans falling between tournament and pair bonding species. Polygamy is present in many cultures, but most individuals are monogamous. Principles of evolution and logic used to understand how the problems of optimising are used to find solution of evolutionary structure, functioning and  upbringing.  That is principles helps you to look in past and make conclusions.  Sociobiology to evolutionary psychology. The notion that you can't understand human behaviour and internal psychological states without evolution.  Logic of Darwinian evolution:  a) There are traits that are heritable. b) There is variatiability among traits. c) Some versions of those traits(ones favouring the circumstances/environment) are more adaptive than others.  Same logic with behaviour. Inheritable. Variations because of mutations. Some are more adaptive than behaviours.  Assumption: Certain behaviours have genetic components.  Unlearn the learned. Example: Animals behave for the good of species. Not survival of the fittest.   Building blocks for behaviour :   When actually, animals behave in order to maximize the number of copies of genes they can pass on to next generation. Sometimes, it may look as if it's for the good of species.  a) Individual selection (reproductive success of an individual. Passing of your own genes) and sexual selection (might not favour environment but some animals still preferring those traits). Usually contradicting each other.  b) Kin selection: Helping out relatives in terms of increasing their reproductive success. Animals cooperating with relatives but as a function of how closely related they are. Animals understand kinship. Evolution has endowned with ability to optimise behaviour along lines of relatedness. Lay down life for two siblings or eight cousins.  c) System of reciprocal altruism among non-relatives. Usually smart animals . Possibility of cheating. When is optimal to co-operate and when is optimal to cheat . Prisoner's Dilemma- Tit for tat( usually in an iterated game). The incentives matter a lot. Forgiving for Tit for tat is better but there is vulnerability of being exploited. Start off with Tit for tat, when trust arises, switch to forgiving for Tit for tat.  Look for games inside games. World is complicated.  Tournament species vs Pair bonding species. We are somewhere in the middle.

That's... not at all what was said. I'll try to explain why it isn't, but you strike me as someone who will hear what they want regardless.  The example given was between two different species; one where males and females are the same size on average, and another where males are larger on average. Which is when the first stone tools appeared (marking the emergence of homo). Technology crawled along for the next 2 million years to even get to the Iron Age.
